title: Introduction to Debate — Structure and Persuasion
description: Students learn the foundational structure of formal debate, including claim, evidence, and reasoning. They examine how effective debaters construct arguments and practice distinguishing between strong and weak evidence to support a position.
instructions:
1. Define debate as a structured discussion where two sides present arguments on a topic.
2. Explain the basic debate structure: opening statement, arguments, rebuttals, closing statement.
3. Introduce the CER framework: Claim (your position), Evidence (facts that support it), Reasoning (why the evidence matters).
4. Model building a CER argument on a simple topic: 'Schools should have longer recess.'
5. Discuss types of evidence: statistics, expert opinions, examples, analogies.
6. Practice distinguishing strong evidence from weak evidence.
7. Introduce logical fallacies to watch for: ad hominem, false dichotomy, appeal to emotion without evidence.
8. Students practice building CER arguments on assigned topics.
9. Share arguments and evaluate evidence strength.
10. Discuss: Why is the ability to argue logically important in a democracy?

slides.heading: Introduction to Debate
slides.subheading: Building Arguments with Structure and Evidence
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to learn about: debate! It's all about how to build really strong arguments by using a clear structure and good evidence. Think of it like building with LEGOs – you need the right pieces and a plan to make something cool and sturdy.

slides.setup_instructions: Display the debate structure poster. Distribute CER reference cards and logical fallacies sheets. Prepare evidence sorting cards with examples of strong and weak evidence for the same claim.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this slide, we're gathering our debate tools. You've got a reference card for the CER framework, which is super helpful, and a poster showing the whole debate structure. We also have cards to practice telling strong evidence from weak evidence, a list of topics to debate, a sheet about tricky arguments called fallacies, and of course, paper and pencils to write everything down.

slides.text: A DEBATE is not an argument or a fight — it is a structured, respectful exchange of ideas where both sides present evidence to support their position. Debating teaches you to think critically, communicate clearly, and consider perspectives different from your own. These skills are essential in school, careers, and civic life.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this step is explaining what a debate really is. It's not just yelling at each other; it's a respectful way to talk about different ideas, where each side tries to convince the other using facts. Learning this helps you think better and explain your ideas clearly, which is useful for pretty much everything you'll do.

slides.text: Every debate argument uses the CER framework: CLAIM — a clear statement of your position ('Schools should have 30-minute recesses'). EVIDENCE — specific facts, data, or examples that support your claim ('Studies show students who have longer recess score 15% higher on afternoon tests'). REASONING — explains WHY the evidence supports the claim ('This shows that physical activity improves focus and academic performance').
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the heart of building an argument – the CER framework! CER stands for Claim, Evidence, and Reasoning. Your Claim is what you believe, the Evidence is the proof you have, and the Reasoning is explaining *why* that proof makes your claim true. It's like saying "I want pizza" (Claim), "because it's delicious and I'm hungry" (Evidence/Reasoning).

slides.text: Not all evidence is equal. STRONG evidence includes: verified statistics, expert opinions, scientific studies, and well-documented examples. WEAK evidence includes: personal anecdotes presented as proof, unverified claims, emotional appeals without facts, and opinions stated as facts. A good debater uses the strongest available evidence.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're talking about the *kind* of proof you use. Strong evidence is like solid facts, numbers from real studies, or what experts say, while weak evidence is more like just saying "I feel this way" or repeating something you heard without checking if it's true. Using strong evidence makes your argument way more believable.

slides.text: Watch out for LOGICAL FALLACIES — errors in reasoning that sound convincing but are not valid. AD HOMINEM: attacking the person instead of their argument. FALSE DICHOTOMY: presenting only two options when more exist. APPEAL TO EMOTION: using feelings instead of facts. BANDWAGON: 'Everyone thinks so, so it must be true.' Recognizing fallacies makes you a stronger thinker and debater.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide warns us about "logical fallacies," which are like sneaky tricks in arguments that sound good but aren't actually logical. For example, attacking the person instead of their idea, or saying something is true just because lots of people believe it. Knowing these helps you spot them and avoid using them yourself.

slides.prompt: Build your first debate argument: (1) Choose a topic from the list or propose your own. (2) Write a clear CLAIM statement. (3) Find or create three pieces of EVIDENCE — rate each as strong or weak and explain why. (4) Write REASONING for each piece of evidence explaining why it supports your claim. (5) Review the logical fallacies sheet — does your argument accidentally contain any? Fix them. (6) Share your CER argument with a partner who disagrees. Can they identify weaknesses? Revise based on feedback.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to build your very own argument! Pick a topic, state your main point clearly (that's your Claim), then find three pieces of proof (Evidence) and explain why they matter for your point (Reasoning). Make sure your evidence is strong and that you haven't accidentally used any of those tricky fallacies we just talked about.

slides.text: Debate is not about winning — it is about thinking clearly and communicating persuasively with evidence. The CER framework you learned today is the foundation of every strong argument, whether in a formal debate, a persuasive essay, or a discussion about an important issue. Tomorrow, we will learn how to anticipate and respond to opposing arguments through rebuttals.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student construct a debate argument using the CER framework, distinguish between strong and weak evidence, and identify common logical fallacies?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our wrap-up for today, celebrating that you've learned how to build a solid argument using CER. Remember, debate is all about clear thinking and using good evidence, not just winning. You've built your first argument, learned to spot weak evidence, and recognized those tricky fallacies!

parent_notes: Debate skills are among the most valuable communication tools your child can develop. They learn not just to argue a point, but to think critically about evidence quality and logical reasoning. Practice at home by discussing topics where family members have different views — model respectful disagreement supported by reasons. The CER framework (Claim, Evidence, Reasoning) transfers to persuasive writing, science explanations, and everyday decision-making. Encourage your child to question evidence they encounter in media: Is it strong or weak? Is there a logical fallacy?

title: Introduction to Variables — Letters That Stand for Numbers
description: Students are introduced to the concept of variables as letters that represent unknown or changing numbers. They learn to write and evaluate simple algebraic expressions, connecting variables to patterns and real-world situations they already understand.
instructions:
1. Pose a mystery: 'I am thinking of a number. When I add 5 to it, I get 12. What is my number?'
2. Introduce the variable as a letter that represents an unknown number.
3. Write the mystery as an equation: x + 5 = 12.
4. Discuss why mathematicians use variables: efficiency and generalization.
5. Practice translating word phrases into algebraic expressions.
6. Introduce evaluation: replacing a variable with a number to find the value.
7. Evaluate expressions for given values of the variable.
8. Connect variables to patterns: the nth term of a sequence.
9. Students practice writing and evaluating expressions.
10. Discuss: How do variables help us describe rules and patterns?

slides.heading: Introduction to Variables
slides.subheading: Letters That Stand for Numbers
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to learn about: variables! Think of them like secret codes in math. Instead of always writing out a full sentence to describe a number we don't know, we can use a letter, and that's what this lesson is all about.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare algebra tiles or colored chips to represent variables and constants visually. Print expression translation worksheets and evaluation practice sheets. Have pattern sequence cards ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for this adventure! We've got some definition cards to help us remember what variables are, a worksheet for practicing turning words into math code, and some practice problems to get really good at using those codes. We also have some cool algebra tiles or colored chips that are like little building blocks to help us *see* what the variables and numbers look like. And don't forget your paper and pencil to write everything down!

slides.text: A VARIABLE is a letter that stands for a number — usually a number we do not know yet or a number that can change. Instead of saying 'some number plus five equals twelve,' mathematicians write: x + 5 = 12. The letter x is the variable. It represents the unknown number we want to find. Any letter can be a variable: n, y, a, t.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is showing us the main idea: a variable is just a letter, like 'x' or 'n', that stands for a number we don't know yet. So, instead of saying "I'm thinking of a number, and if I add 5 to it, I get 12," we can write it super short as 'x + 5 = 12'. That 'x' is our secret number, our variable!

slides.text: TRANSLATING words into algebra: 'a number plus 7' becomes n + 7. 'Three times a number' becomes 3n (or 3 x n). 'A number minus 4' becomes n - 4. 'A number divided by 2' becomes n/2. Key vocabulary: 'plus/added to/sum' = addition. 'Times/product/of' = multiplication. 'Minus/difference/less than' = subtraction. 'Divided by/quotient' = division.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to practice turning everyday phrases into this math code. For example, "a number plus 7" can be written as 'n + 7', and "three times a number" becomes '3n'. Pay attention to the keywords: "plus" means add, "times" means multiply, "minus" means subtract, and "divided by" means division. It's like learning a secret language!

slides.text: EVALUATING an expression means replacing the variable with a specific number and calculating. If n = 4, then 3n + 2 = 3(4) + 2 = 12 + 2 = 14. To evaluate: (1) Write the expression. (2) Replace every n with the given number. (3) Follow order of operations. (4) Calculate the result. Practice: If x = 5, what is 2x - 3? Answer: 2(5) - 3 = 10 - 3 = 7.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is called "evaluating," and it's like solving a puzzle. If we know what number the variable stands for, we can plug it in and find the answer. So, if 'n' is supposed to be 4, and we have the expression '3n + 2', we swap the 'n' for '4' to get '3(4) + 2', which equals 12 + 2, giving us 14. You just replace the letter with the number and do the math.

slides.text: Variables help us describe PATTERNS. Look at the pattern 3, 6, 9, 12... The rule is 'multiply the position by 3.' Position 1: 3(1)=3. Position 2: 3(2)=6. Position n: 3n. Now you can find ANY term. The 100th term? 3(100)=300. Variables turn specific examples into general rules that work for any number.
slides.mascot_explanation: Variables are super useful for spotting and describing patterns, which is pretty awesome. Think about the pattern 3, 6, 9, 12... See how each number is just the position number multiplied by 3? We can write that rule as '3n', where 'n' is the position. This means we can find *any* number in that pattern, like the 100th one, just by calculating 3 times 100.

slides.prompt: Practice with variables: (1) Translate 10 word phrases into algebraic expressions (use the worksheet). (2) Evaluate these expressions for x = 3: 4x, x + 10, 2x - 1, x/3 + 5, 3x + 7. (3) Find the rule for each pattern and write it with a variable: Pattern A: 5, 10, 15, 20... Pattern B: 2, 5, 8, 11... Pattern C: 1, 4, 9, 16... (4) Use your rule to find the 20th term of each pattern. (5) Challenge: Write your own pattern, find the algebraic rule, and test it with a partner.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to put on your detective hats and practice! You'll translate some phrases into math language, then use the numbers they give you to figure out what those math expressions equal. After that, you'll look at some number patterns, figure out the secret rule using a variable, and then use that rule to find a number way down the line in the pattern. It's like solving a bunch of mini-mysteries!

slides.text: Variables are the gateway to algebra — one of the most powerful branches of mathematics. Today you learned that a single letter can represent any number, and that expressions with variables can describe patterns and relationships. Tomorrow, we will use variables to write and solve EQUATIONS — finding the mystery number that makes a mathematical sentence true.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student define what a variable is, translate word phrases into algebraic expressions, evaluate expressions for given values, and use variables to describe pattern rules?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you've done a fantastic job today exploring variables! You learned that letters can be placeholders for numbers, and how we can use them to translate word problems and even describe patterns like a super-smart code writer. Tomorrow, we'll take this even further and use these variable skills to solve for those mystery numbers in equations.

parent_notes: Variables are the bridge between arithmetic and algebra. This lesson introduces a concept your child will use throughout middle school, high school, and beyond. The key insight is that letters in math are not mysterious — they simply stand for numbers we have not identified yet. At home, create simple variable problems: 'I bought some apples at $2 each and spent $10. How many apples did I buy?' (2a = 10, a = 5). If your child is comfortable with variables, they are ready for algebra. If they find the concept abstract, use algebra tiles or physical objects to make it concrete.

title: The Rise of Dictators — Seeds of World War II
description: Students examine how the aftermath of World War I and the Great Depression created conditions for the rise of dictators in Europe and Asia. They study how Adolf Hitler, Benito Mussolini, and Emperor Hirohito gained power and how democratic institutions failed to prevent authoritarian rule.
instructions:
1. Connect to the Treaty of Versailles from last week: how did it affect Germany?
2. Describe the economic devastation of the Great Depression across Europe.
3. Explain how economic hardship and national humiliation create vulnerability to extreme leaders.
4. Introduce Adolf Hitler and the Nazi Party's rise in Germany.
5. Introduce Mussolini and Fascism in Italy.
6. Discuss Japanese militarism and expansion in Asia.
7. Compare the tactics each dictator used to gain power: propaganda, scapegoating, promises of glory.
8. Discuss how democratic institutions were weakened or destroyed.
9. Students create a comparison chart of the three dictators and their methods.
10. Discuss: What warning signs indicate a democracy is in danger?

slides.heading: The Rise of Dictators
slides.subheading: How World War I's Aftermath Led to Authoritarianism
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our history lesson. It's telling us we're going to learn about how some powerful leaders, called dictators, took over in different countries after World War I. It also hints that the problems after that big war helped these dictators get into power.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare an age-appropriate reading packet on the rise of Hitler, Mussolini, and Japanese militarism. Create a comparison chart organizer with columns for each leader and rows for tactics. Display the 1930s world map.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is a shopping list for our history project! You'll need that reading packet to learn about Hitler, Mussolini, and Japan's leaders, and the comparison chart is where we'll keep track of all their tricks. We've got a map to see where all this happened, some examples of how these leaders used propaganda (which is like misleading ads), a timeline to put events in order, and pencils to do all our writing and coloring. Go grab all these things with a grown-up's help!

slides.text: After WWI, Europe was devastated. Germany was humiliated by the Treaty of Versailles and crushed by reparation debts. Then the GREAT DEPRESSION (1929) brought mass unemployment and poverty worldwide. When people are desperate, hungry, and angry, they become vulnerable to leaders who promise simple solutions and someone to blame.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is super important because it sets the scene for why dictators even came about. After World War I, Germany was treated really harshly, which made people angry and embarrassed. Then, the Great Depression hit, making everyone super poor and unemployed, which just made things worse. When people are feeling desperate and upset, they become more likely to listen to someone who promises easy fixes, even if those promises are dangerous.

slides.text: In Germany, ADOLF HITLER and the Nazi Party rose to power by blaming Germany's problems on the Treaty of Versailles, Jewish people, and democratic 'weakness.' Hitler promised to restore Germany's greatness. He used powerful propaganda, rallies, and fear to gain support, then destroyed democratic institutions once in power. By 1933, he was dictator.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we learn about Adolf Hitler in Germany. He and his Nazi Party were really good at blaming other people, especially Jewish people and the government, for all of Germany's problems. Hitler promised to make Germany strong and respected again, using exciting rallies and controlling what people saw and heard to get them on his side. By 1933, he had taken over completely, becoming a dictator.

slides.text: In Italy, BENITO MUSSOLINI created FASCISM — a system where the state has total power, individuality is crushed, and military strength is glorified. He came to power in 1922 using violence and intimidation. In Japan, military leaders gained control of the government and pursued aggressive expansion in Asia, invading Manchuria (China) in 1931.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part introduces Benito Mussolini in Italy and what happened in Japan. Mussolini created Fascism, a system where the government has all the power and military strength is super important. He used force and threats to become leader in 1922. In Japan, military leaders took charge and started taking over parts of China, showing they wanted to expand their power too.

slides.text: All three used similar tactics: (1) PROPAGANDA — controlling information and spreading lies. (2) SCAPEGOATING — blaming problems on minority groups. (3) NATIONALISM — extreme pride that views other nations as inferior. (4) MILITARY BUILDUP — building armies to project power. (5) SUPPRESSION OF OPPOSITION — silencing critics, banning other political parties, controlling the press.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide breaks down the sneaky tricks these dictators used to gain and keep power. They all used propaganda to spread their message, blamed problems on minority groups (scapegoating), pushed extreme national pride, built up their armies, and shut down anyone who disagreed with them. Understanding these tactics helps us see how they fooled people and took away their freedoms.

slides.prompt: Create a comparison chart: (1) List Hitler, Mussolini, and Japanese military leaders in three columns. (2) For each, record: country, year they gained power, promises they made, groups they scapegoated, how they destroyed democracy, and territories they seized. (3) Add key dates to your WWII timeline. (4) Write a reflection paragraph: What conditions allow dictators to rise? What are the warning signs that a democracy is in danger? (5) Discuss: How can citizens protect democracy?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the historian! You'll fill out that comparison chart using the reading packet, noting down key details about each leader like when they took power and what they promised. Then, add important dates to your timeline. Finally, you'll write a paragraph about what makes societies vulnerable to dictators and what signs show a democracy might be in trouble.

slides.text: The rise of dictators teaches us that democracy is not automatic — it must be actively protected. When people are desperate, when propaganda goes unchallenged, and when scapegoating replaces critical thinking, even the most advanced societies can fall into authoritarianism. Understanding HOW it happened is the first step in making sure it does not happen again.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain the conditions that allowed dictators to rise, compare the tactics of Hitler, Mussolini, and Japanese militarists, and discuss how democratic institutions can be protected?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide wraps everything up by reminding us why this is so important. It teaches us that keeping democracy safe takes effort from everyone. When people are struggling, when lies spread easily, and when we blame groups instead of solving problems, even strong countries can lose their freedom. Knowing how this happened in the past is our best tool to prevent it from happening again.

parent_notes: This lesson addresses difficult but essential history. Understanding how dictators rise to power is a critical civic education objective. The lesson focuses on political and economic factors rather than graphic violence. Your child may have questions about Hitler, the Nazis, and the events that follow — answer honestly and age-appropriately. Emphasize that understanding these events helps us recognize warning signs in our own world. The discussion about protecting democracy connects history to present-day civic responsibility. Next week's lessons on the Holocaust will require careful emotional preparation.

title: Axis vs. Allies — Mapping the World at War
description: Students map the global alliances of World War II, identifying the Axis powers, Allied powers, and neutral nations. They analyze how geography influenced military strategy, supply lines, and the course of the war on multiple continents.
instructions:
1. Introduce the two opposing sides of WWII: Axis and Allied powers.
2. Identify the major Axis powers: Germany, Italy, Japan and their territories.
3. Identify the major Allied powers: Britain, France, Soviet Union, United States, China.
4. Locate neutral nations and discuss why some chose neutrality.
5. Discuss how geography influenced the war: two-front war for Germany, island-hopping in the Pacific.
6. Examine the concept of supply lines and why geography made them critical.
7. Map the major theaters of war: European, Pacific, North African, Eastern Front.
8. Students color-code a world map showing Axis, Allied, and neutral nations.
9. Add arrows showing major military campaigns and supply routes.
10. Discuss: How did geography give advantages or disadvantages to each side?

slides.heading: Axis vs. Allies
slides.subheading: Mapping the World at War (1939-1945)
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to learn about: World War II, and how we'll be looking at it on a map to see who was fighting who and where. It's like setting the stage for a big history detective story where the clues are on the world map!

slides.setup_instructions: Distribute large blank world maps. Prepare the alliance reference sheet listing all Axis, Allied, and major neutral nations. Have an atlas or globe available for reference. Create theater of war cards with key information.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this activity, we need a few things. You'll need a big blank map of the world to draw on, and then some reference sheets that tell you which countries were on which side and where the big battles happened. We also need colored pencils – think of them as your special tools to show the different teams, and rulers to draw straight lines for troop movements.

slides.text: World War II was truly a WORLD war — fought on every continent except Antarctica. The AXIS POWERS were led by Germany (Hitler), Italy (Mussolini), and Japan (Tojo). They were joined by Hungary, Romania, Bulgaria, and others. The ALLIED POWERS were led by Britain (Churchill), the Soviet Union (Stalin), and the United States (Roosevelt), joined by France, China, Canada, Australia, and many others.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding the two main teams in World War II: the Axis powers and the Allied powers. The Axis were mainly Germany, Italy, and Japan, while the Allies included big players like Britain, the Soviet Union, and the United States. It's like knowing which kids are on which team before a big game starts.

slides.text: Look at the map and notice Germany's geographic problem: enemies on BOTH sides. Britain and France to the west, the Soviet Union to the east. Fighting a TWO-FRONT WAR meant splitting forces and supply lines. Japan faced a different geographic challenge: it needed oil and resources from distant Pacific islands, requiring a vast navy to control sea lanes.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this slide is showing us how where countries are on the map really messed with how they fought the war. Germany, for example, had enemies on both sides, which is a huge headache, and Japan had to sail super far to get important stuff like oil. It's like trying to play tag with people chasing you from all directions!

slides.text: The war was fought in multiple THEATERS: (1) EUROPEAN THEATER — from the invasion of Poland to D-Day and the fall of Berlin. (2) EASTERN FRONT — Germany vs. Soviet Union, the deadliest theater. (3) PACIFIC THEATER — island-by-island fighting across the vast Pacific Ocean. (4) NORTH AFRICAN THEATER — battles across Libya, Egypt, Tunisia, and Morocco.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to look at the different "playgrounds" where the war happened, called theaters. Think of them like different zones on a game board: there was Europe, the massive Pacific Ocean, and even North Africa. Each place had its own challenges because of the land and sea.

slides.text: SUPPLY LINES were as important as battles. Armies need food, fuel, ammunition, and medicine. The ATLANTIC shipping lanes from the U.S. to Britain were targeted by German submarines. Japan's dependence on oil from Southeast Asia made those supply routes critical. Geographic control of straits, channels, and ports often determined who won.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is super important because armies need tons of supplies, like food and bullets, to fight. This slide explains that getting those supplies to the soldiers was a big deal, and controlling the oceans and seas where ships traveled was key. It's like making sure your favorite snacks can get to you when you're playing a long game.

slides.prompt: Create a detailed WWII world map: (1) Color Axis nations in one color and Allied nations in another. Use a third color for neutral nations. (2) Mark the four major theaters of war with labels. (3) Draw arrows showing major military campaigns: Germany's invasion of Poland and France, Japan's Pacific expansion, the Allied D-Day invasion, and the Soviet push west. (4) Draw dotted lines showing critical supply routes across the Atlantic and Pacific. (5) Write a paragraph: Choose one theater and explain how geography shaped the fighting there.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to be the map maker! You're going to use your colored pencils to show who was on which team by coloring in the countries, then draw lines to show where the fighting happened and where the supplies traveled. It’s like creating your own awesome history comic book on the map.

slides.text: World War II was shaped by geography at every level — from the two-front problem that doomed Germany to the vast Pacific distances that challenged both Japan and the Allies. Understanding the geographic dimensions of the war helps us see why certain strategies succeeded and others failed. Maps do not just show where things happened — they help explain WHY they happened.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify and map the Axis and Allied powers, describe the four major theaters of war, explain how geography influenced military strategy, and discuss the importance of supply lines?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've reached the end! This slide is just a reminder that maps are like secret codes that help us understand *why* things happened in history, not just *where*. You just finished creating a super detailed map that shows all the major players and movements of World War II – that's awesome!

parent_notes: Mapping WWII alliances gives your child a global perspective on the war and develops geographic literacy. The concept of supply lines and strategic geography teaches systems thinking — understanding how parts connect to affect the whole. You can extend this lesson with documentary footage showing the geographic challenges of each theater. The key insight is that geography is not just background — it actively shapes historical events. If your child has family connections to WWII (many families do), sharing those stories adds personal meaning to the geographic and historical content.

title: Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry — Chapters 5-6: Cassie's Awakening
description: Students continue reading the novel as Cassie experiences racial humiliation firsthand during the trip to Strawberry. They analyze how this pivotal moment changes Cassie's understanding of her world and discuss the difference between knowing about injustice and experiencing it personally.
instructions:
1. Review events from Chapters 3-4 and check predictions from last session.
2. Read Chapter 5: the trip to Strawberry and the incident at the Barnett store.
3. Pause to discuss Cassie's shock when Mr. Barnett serves white customers first despite her being there first.
4. Continue reading the encounter with Lillian Jean Simms on the sidewalk.
5. Discuss Big Ma's forced apology and what it costs her dignity.
6. Read Chapter 6 and Uncle Hammer's furious reaction.
7. Analyze the contrast between Big Ma's caution and Uncle Hammer's anger.
8. Discuss: Why do different characters respond to injustice differently?
9. Students write journal responses analyzing Cassie's changing perspective.
10. Connect to theme: the loss of innocence when confronting systemic injustice.
materials_needed: Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry by Mildred Taylor

slides.heading: Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry
slides.subheading: Chapters 5-6: Cassie's Awakening
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is just showing us the title of what we're reading and which chapters we're focusing on: "Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry," specifically chapters 5 and 6, which are all about Cassie starting to understand things differently. It's like the beginning of a big shift for her in the story.

items: Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry by Mildred Taylor
slides.setup_instructions: Have the novel ready at Chapter 5. Prepare discussion questions focused on Cassie's perspective shift. Have students retrieve their character maps, reading journals, and symbolism trackers.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is like our toolkit for today's reading adventure. We've got the actual book, "Roll of Thunder, Hear My Cry," which you'll need to have open to chapter 5. Then there are your reading journals where you'll write down your thoughts, a character development tracker to keep tabs on how people are changing, some discussion question cards to get us thinking, and a symbolism tracking sheet that we'll keep adding to. Don't forget your pencils to write with!

slides.text: Chapters 5-6 are the turning point of the novel. Until now, Cassie has been somewhat sheltered on the family's land. The trip to STRAWBERRY forces her to confront the full reality of racism — not as something she has heard about, but as something happening TO HER. This shift from secondhand knowledge to personal experience is devastating and transformative.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is telling us that chapters 5 and 6 are super important – they're like the moment Cassie's whole world view gets shaken up. Up until now, she's been mostly safe on her family's land, but the trip to Strawberry is going to show her what racism is really like, not just something she's heard about, but something that happens directly to her.

slides.text: At the Barnett store, Mr. Barnett deliberately serves white customers who arrived after Cassie. When Cassie speaks up — because she has been raised to believe in fairness — she is humiliated. Then on the sidewalk, Lillian Jean Simms demands Cassie step off into the road. Big Ma forces Cassie to apologize. Pay attention to what each character FEELS versus what they are forced to DO.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this part describes what happens in Strawberry. At the store, the owner serves white people before Cassie, even though she was there first. When she speaks up, she's embarrassed, and then on the sidewalk, a white girl named Lillian Jean makes her move into the dusty road. Pay close attention to how Cassie feels versus what she's forced to do and say.

slides.text: Big Ma's response seems like surrender, but Taylor shows us it is SURVIVAL STRATEGY. Big Ma knows the dangers of defiance in 1930s Mississippi. Uncle Hammer's furious reaction represents the opposite impulse — to fight back immediately. Neither response is wrong; they reflect different calculations about risk, safety, and dignity under an oppressive system.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains that Big Ma's decision to make Cassie apologize might look like she's giving up, but it's actually a smart way to keep them safe in a dangerous time. Uncle Hammer, on the other hand, is really angry and wants to fight back right away. It shows how different people deal with unfairness in different ways, depending on what they think is most important at that moment.

slides.text: This is a COMING-OF-AGE moment for Cassie. She is losing her innocence — the belief that the world is fair and that being right is enough. This theme, the painful gap between how the world SHOULD work and how it DOES work, is central to the novel. As readers, we feel Cassie's outrage and confusion because Taylor has made us see through her eyes.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a really big deal for Cassie because she's losing her childhood innocence – that idea that the world is always fair and that doing the right thing is always enough. The story is showing us the tough difference between how things *should* be and how they *actually* are, and it makes us feel Cassie's anger and confusion because we're seeing it all through her eyes.

slides.prompt: In your reading journal: (1) Describe the Strawberry incidents in detail — what happened at the store and on the sidewalk. (2) Analyze Big Ma's decision to make Cassie apologize. Why did she do it? Was she right? Write arguments for both sides. (3) Compare Big Ma's response with Uncle Hammer's. What does each value most — safety or dignity? (4) Track Cassie's character development: how has she changed from Chapter 1 to Chapter 6? (5) Update your symbolism tracker with any new symbols you notice.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, now it's your turn to write in your journal! First, describe everything that happened in Strawberry, both at the store and with Lillian Jean. Then, think about why Big Ma made Cassie apologize and if that was the right thing to do, considering both sides. After that, compare Big Ma's reaction to Uncle Hammer's – what do they each care about more, staying safe or standing up for themselves? Finally, write down how Cassie has changed since the beginning of the book and add any new symbols you noticed to your tracker.

slides.text: Cassie's experience in Strawberry is one of the most powerful scenes in children's literature because it shows the moment when a child realizes the world is not fair — and that the unfairness is deliberate and systemic. Taylor does not soften this reality, and that honesty is what makes the novel so important and enduring.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe the pivotal events in Strawberry, analyze the different responses of Big Ma and Uncle Hammer, and explain how these chapters represent Cassie's loss of innocence?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last part is reminding us how powerful Cassie's experience in Strawberry is because it's the moment she realizes the world isn't fair and that this unfairness is intentional. It's important because author Mildred Taylor doesn't shy away from this difficult truth, which is what makes the story so meaningful and memorable.

parent_notes: These chapters are emotionally intense and may prompt strong reactions from your child. Cassie's humiliation at the store and on the sidewalk, and Big Ma's forced apology, are deeply unfair — and your child will feel that injustice. This is valuable; empathy is built through experiencing others' stories. Discuss the impossible choices faced by Black families in the Jim Crow South: balancing dignity with physical safety. The comparison between Big Ma's caution and Uncle Hammer's anger reflects a real historical debate within the Black community about the best response to oppression — a debate that continued through the civil rights movement.

title: Building Rebuttals — Anticipating and Countering Arguments
description: Students learn the art of rebuttal by practicing how to anticipate opposing arguments, acknowledge them respectfully, and counter them with evidence. They develop active listening skills essential for effective debate and learn structured response frameworks.
instructions:
1. Review the CER framework from Day 1.
2. Define rebuttal: responding to an opponent's argument with evidence and reasoning.
3. Introduce the ACE rebuttal framework: Acknowledge, Counter, Evidence.
4. Model listening to an argument and constructing an ACE rebuttal.
5. Discuss the importance of respectful language in rebuttals.
6. Practice identifying the weakest point in an opponent's argument.
7. Introduce the concept of concession: agreeing with part of an opponent's point before countering.
8. Students practice rebuttals in pairs with structured debate topics.
9. Switch sides: argue the opposite position to build perspective-taking skills.
10. Reflect: How does considering the other side strengthen your own argument?

slides.heading: Building Rebuttals
slides.subheading: Anticipating and Countering Opposing Arguments
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is all about "rebuttals," which basically means how to respond when someone disagrees with you, especially in a debate. It's like figuring out the best way to answer a challenge by showing why your idea is still strong, even when someone else has a different one.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare paired debate topic cards where each pair contains two opposing positions on the same issue. Print ACE framework cards and respectful language sentence starters. Arrange seating for face-to-face partner work.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide lists all the tools we'll need for our debate practice. We've got cards with our debate topics, a handy guide for the ACE rebuttal method, some helpful phrases for talking respectfully, and a checklist to make sure we're really listening. You'll need to grab these so we can get started.

slides.text: A REBUTTAL is your response to the other side's argument. Strong debaters do not just present their own case — they directly address and dismantle their opponent's points. The ACE framework guides you: ACKNOWLEDGE what the opponent said (show you listened). COUNTER with your opposing point. Provide EVIDENCE to support your counter.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step explains what a rebuttal really is: it's your direct answer to someone else's point, and it's super important in any kind of discussion or debate. The ACE method is a cool way to build a strong rebuttal: first, you Acknowledge what they said to show you heard them, then you Counter their point with your own idea, and finally, you back it up with Evidence.

slides.text: Respectful language matters. Instead of 'That is wrong,' say 'I understand that perspective, but the evidence suggests otherwise.' Instead of 'That makes no sense,' say 'While that point has merit, I would argue that...' Respectful rebuttals are MORE persuasive because they show you are thoughtful and fair-minded, not just aggressive.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is all about *how* you say things when you're rebutting, because being polite makes a huge difference. Instead of just saying "that's wrong," you can say something like "I see your point, but here's what the facts show," which sounds much more convincing and less confrontational.

slides.text: STRATEGIC REBUTTAL: Target the weakest point in your opponent's argument. Every argument has strengths and weaknesses. A skilled debater listens carefully to find the point with the weakest evidence or the biggest logical gap. You do not need to counter everything — focus on the most vulnerable claim and dismantle it thoroughly.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we learn a smart strategy for rebuttals: focus on the weakest part of the other person's argument, not necessarily everything they said. Think of it like finding the one loose brick in a wall – if you can knock that one out, the whole section might crumble, making your point much stronger.

slides.text: The CONCESSION technique is powerful: agree with part of your opponent's argument before countering. 'My opponent makes a valid point that exercise is important; however, extending the school day would reduce time for family activities, which research shows is equally critical for child development.' Conceding a small point makes your rebuttal more credible.
slides.mascot_explanation: This cool trick is called "concession," and it's like giving a little nod to your opponent before you make your main point. You can say something like, "You're right that X is important," but then follow up with "however, we also need to consider Y," which shows you're fair and makes your main counter-argument sound even more powerful.

slides.prompt: Rebuttal Practice: (1) Draw a debate topic card. Prepare a 1-minute CER argument for your assigned side. (2) Present your argument to your partner. Partner listens actively and takes notes. (3) Partner delivers an ACE rebuttal using respectful language. (4) SWITCH SIDES — now argue the OPPOSITE position. This builds empathy and perspective-taking. (5) After both rounds, discuss: Which rebuttals were most effective? Why? What was it like to argue for a side you disagree with? (6) Write a reflection: How does understanding the other side strengthen your own position?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to put it all together! You'll grab a debate topic, get ready to argue for one side, and then your partner will practice giving you an ACE rebuttal. Then, you'll switch sides and do it all again, which is a great way to understand different viewpoints.

slides.text: The ability to rebut respectfully is one of the most important communication skills you can develop. It requires deep listening, quick thinking, and the humility to acknowledge valid points from the other side. Arguing the opposite position is especially powerful — it forces you to see the world through someone else's eyes, which always makes you a better thinker.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student construct a rebuttal using the ACE framework, use respectful debate language, identify weaknesses in opposing arguments, and argue effectively from either side of a debate topic?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've wrapped up our practice, and you've done an awesome job learning to build strong arguments and respond thoughtfully to others! You practiced listening carefully, countering respectfully, and even arguing from a side you might not agree with, which is a really powerful way to become a better communicator and thinker.

parent_notes: Rebuttal skills teach your child to disagree respectfully and think critically — essential life skills. The exercise of arguing the opposite side is particularly valuable because it builds empathy and intellectual flexibility. At home, try 'devil's advocate' discussions where family members argue positions they do not actually hold. The respectful language practice transfers to all areas of life — siblings' disputes, classroom discussions, and future workplace interactions. If your child struggles with the idea of arguing for something they disagree with, explain that understanding all sides makes their OWN argument stronger.

title: Solving Simple Equations — Finding the Unknown
description: Students learn to solve one-step equations using inverse operations. They develop conceptual understanding through balance scale models before transitioning to algebraic methods, connecting equation-solving to real-world problem scenarios.
instructions:
1. Review variables and expressions from the previous lesson.
2. Define an equation as a mathematical sentence with an equals sign.
3. Introduce the balance scale model: both sides must stay equal.
4. Demonstrate solving addition equations: x + 5 = 12 (subtract 5 from both sides).
5. Demonstrate solving subtraction equations: x - 3 = 8 (add 3 to both sides).
6. Demonstrate solving multiplication equations: 3x = 15 (divide both sides by 3).
7. Demonstrate solving division equations: x/4 = 6 (multiply both sides by 4).
8. Introduce the concept of inverse operations.
9. Students practice solving one-step equations.
10. Apply equation-solving to word problems.

slides.heading: Solving Simple Equations
slides.subheading: Using Inverse Operations to Find the Unknown
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this first slide is like the cover page for our adventure into solving equations! It tells us we're going to learn how to find missing numbers, called "unknowns," by using what we call "inverse operations." Think of it like being a detective and figuring out a secret number that makes a math sentence true.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a balance scale demonstration (physical or drawn on the board). Prepare algebra tiles for hands-on equation solving. Print practice worksheets with one-step equations of all four operation types.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is all about the tools we'll need. We've got a balance scale – this is super important because it shows us that equations need to stay equal on both sides, just like a real scale. Algebra tiles are like little building blocks to help us see how the numbers and letters work together. The worksheet, word cards, and reference card are for practicing, and paper and pencils are for doing all the problem-solving. Make sure you have all these ready, maybe ask a grown-up to help gather them!

slides.text: An EQUATION is like a balanced scale — whatever is on the left side EQUALS whatever is on the right side. To keep it balanced, anything you do to one side, you MUST do to the other side. This is the golden rule of algebra: KEEP THE BALANCE. If x + 5 = 12, and you subtract 5 from the left, you must subtract 5 from the right too.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is the most important rule for solving equations: it's all about keeping things balanced! Imagine a real scale with weights on both sides – if you add or take away something from one side, you have to do the exact same thing to the other side to keep it from tipping over. That's what we'll do with our equations to figure out the missing number.

slides.text: INVERSE OPERATIONS undo each other. Addition and subtraction are inverses. Multiplication and division are inverses. To solve an equation, use the inverse operation to isolate the variable (get x alone). Example: x + 5 = 12. The 5 is ADDED, so use the inverse — SUBTRACT 5 from both sides. x + 5 - 5 = 12 - 5. x = 7. Check: 7 + 5 = 12. Correct!
slides.mascot_explanation: So, this is where we learn the secret handshake for solving equations: inverse operations! They're like opposite actions that cancel each other out. For example, adding and subtracting are opposites. If you see a number being added to our mystery number (like 'x + 5'), you do the opposite – subtract it – from *both* sides of the equation to get 'x' all by itself.

slides.text: More examples: (1) x - 3 = 8. The 3 is subtracted, so ADD 3 to both sides. x = 11. Check: 11 - 3 = 8. (2) 3x = 15. The x is multiplied by 3, so DIVIDE both sides by 3. x = 5. Check: 3(5) = 15. (3) x/4 = 6. The x is divided by 4, so MULTIPLY both sides by 4. x = 24. Check: 24/4 = 6.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we're just getting more practice with those opposite operations. If a number is being subtracted, we'll add it to both sides. If the mystery number is being multiplied by something, we'll divide both sides. And if it's being divided, we'll multiply both sides. Each time, we're just doing the opposite to get our mystery number alone.

slides.text: Always CHECK your answer by substituting it back into the original equation. If both sides are equal, you solved correctly. Word problems become equations: 'Maria had some stickers. She gave away 7 and has 15 left. How many did she start with?' Equation: x - 7 = 15. Solve: x = 22. Maria started with 22 stickers.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super cool step because it shows us how to make sure we're right! After you solve an equation, you can plug your answer back into the original problem to see if both sides still match up. It's like checking your work on a puzzle. Plus, we're learning how to turn everyday stories, like Maria giving away stickers, into math equations we can solve.

slides.prompt: Solve and check: (1) Practice set of 12 one-step equations: 3 addition, 3 subtraction, 3 multiplication, 3 division. Show your work and check each answer. (2) Draw three word problem cards. Write an equation for each, solve it, and check your answer. (3) Create your own word problem that requires solving an equation. Write the problem, the equation, and the solution. Exchange with a partner to solve. (4) Challenge: If 2x + 1 = 9, can you figure out what x is? (Hint: work backward.)
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is our chance to be the math detectives! You'll get to practice solving a bunch of different one-step equations, showing all your steps, and then checking your answers. You'll also turn some word problems into equations and solve them, and even create your own! Don't worry if it feels tricky at first, just take it one step at a time.

slides.text: Solving equations is one of the most important skills in all of mathematics. The principle is simple: use inverse operations to isolate the variable, and keep the equation balanced. Every equation you solve is a puzzle with a definite answer, and you now have the tools to find it. Tomorrow, we will tackle more complex equations and real-world applications.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student solve one-step equations using inverse operations for all four operations, check solutions by substitution, and translate word problems into solvable equations?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! We just learned how to be super equation solvers, using those clever inverse operations to find hidden numbers. You practiced turning word problems into math puzzles and checking your answers, which is a really big deal in math. You've got the tools now to solve all sorts of math mysteries!

parent_notes: Equation-solving is the core skill of algebra and one of the most important mathematical abilities your child will develop. The balance scale metaphor makes the abstract concept concrete: whatever you do to one side, you must do to the other. At home, create real-world equations: 'We need 24 cookies for the party. Each batch makes 8. How many batches do we need?' (8b = 24). If your child struggles, return to the balance scale or algebra tiles for hands-on practice. The key is understanding WHY inverse operations work, not just memorizing steps.

title: Types of Energy — Kinetic and Potential
description: Students explore the fundamental forms of energy, focusing on kinetic energy (energy of motion) and potential energy (stored energy). Through experiments with ramps, rubber bands, and pendulums, they observe energy transformations and learn that energy is never created or destroyed, only converted.
instructions:
1. Ask: What is energy? Discuss that energy is the ability to do work or cause change.
2. Introduce the two main categories: kinetic energy (motion) and potential energy (stored).
3. Define kinetic energy with examples: a rolling ball, a running child, flowing water.
4. Define potential energy: gravitational (height), elastic (stretched/compressed), chemical (food/fuel).
5. Demonstrate gravitational potential energy with a ball held at different heights.
6. Demonstrate elastic potential energy with rubber bands.
7. Introduce the Law of Conservation of Energy: energy cannot be created or destroyed.
8. Show energy transformations: potential to kinetic and back.
9. Students conduct pendulum experiments observing energy conversion.
10. Create energy transformation diagrams for everyday scenarios.

slides.heading: Types of Energy
slides.subheading: Kinetic Energy and Potential Energy
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just the title page for our lesson. It's introducing us to the main idea: we're going to learn about the different kinds of energy, specifically how things move (that's kinetic energy) and how things store energy (that's potential energy).

slides.setup_instructions: Set up experiment stations: Station 1 with ramps and balls at different heights, Station 2 with rubber bands and launchers, Station 3 with pendulum materials. Post the energy types reference chart.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide lists all the cool stuff we'll need for our experiments! We've got balls and ramps to see how things roll, rubber bands to show stored energy, and string and washers to make pendulums swing. You'll also need your science journal and pencil to write down what happens, and there's a chart to help you remember the different types of energy. Go grab all these things with a grown-up's help so we can get started!

slides.text: ENERGY is the ability to do work — to push, pull, heat, light, or move something. Energy comes in two fundamental forms: KINETIC ENERGY is the energy of MOTION. Anything moving has kinetic energy — a thrown ball, a flowing river, even the air molecules in a breeze. The faster something moves and the more massive it is, the more kinetic energy it has.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about kinetic energy, which is basically the energy of anything that's moving. Think about when you're running really fast, or a car speeding down the road – they've got kinetic energy because they're in motion! The faster something moves and the heavier it is, the more kinetic energy it has.

slides.text: POTENTIAL ENERGY is STORED energy — energy waiting to be released. GRAVITATIONAL potential energy depends on height: a ball held high has more potential energy than one held low. ELASTIC potential energy is stored in stretched or compressed objects: a pulled-back rubber band, a compressed spring. CHEMICAL potential energy is stored in the bonds of molecules: food, batteries, fuel.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're talking about potential energy, which is like stored-up energy just waiting to be used. There are a few kinds: gravitational is when something is high up, like a ball held way above the ground. Elastic is when something is stretched, like a rubber band pulled back, and chemical energy is stored in things like food or batteries.

slides.text: Energy constantly TRANSFORMS from one type to another. Hold a ball high (gravitational potential energy). Drop it — potential converts to kinetic as it falls. At the bottom, it has maximum kinetic energy. As it bounces back up, kinetic converts back to potential. A pendulum swings back and forth, endlessly converting between potential and kinetic.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows how energy likes to change from one type to another, which is called transformation. Imagine holding a ball up high – that's potential energy. When you let it go, it starts falling, and that potential energy turns into kinetic energy as it speeds up. When it bounces, it goes back and forth between kinetic and potential energy.

slides.text: The LAW OF CONSERVATION OF ENERGY states that energy cannot be created or destroyed — only transformed from one type to another. When a ball stops bouncing, it SEEMS like energy disappeared, but it actually converted to THERMAL energy (heat) and SOUND energy. The total amount of energy in the universe never changes — it just changes form.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important idea called the Law of Conservation of Energy. It means energy can't just disappear, it only changes its form. So, even when a ball stops bouncing and seems like it's not moving anymore, that energy didn't vanish; it just turned into tiny bits of heat or sound that we can't always see.

slides.prompt: Conduct three experiments: (1) RAMP EXPERIMENT: Release a ball from three different heights. Measure how far it rolls on the flat surface. Record data. Explain: How does height (potential energy) affect distance (kinetic energy)? (2) RUBBER BAND EXPERIMENT: Stretch a rubber band to three different lengths and launch a lightweight object. Measure distances. Explain the relationship between elastic potential energy and kinetic energy. (3) PENDULUM EXPERIMENT: Build a simple pendulum. Draw a diagram showing where the pendulum has maximum potential energy and maximum kinetic energy. (4) Create energy transformation diagrams for: eating breakfast, riding a bike downhill, and a flashlight turning on.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time for the fun part – experiments! We'll do three: first, roll balls down ramps from different heights to see how height (potential energy) affects how far they roll (kinetic energy). Then, we'll stretch rubber bands different amounts to see how that changes how far they launch things. Finally, we'll build a pendulum and figure out where it has the most stored energy and the most moving energy. You'll also draw pictures showing how energy changes when you eat or ride a bike.

slides.text: Energy is everywhere, constantly transforming. Every action you take involves energy conversion — eating converts chemical energy to kinetic energy so you can move. The Conservation of Energy is one of the most fundamental laws in all of science. Next lesson, we will explore thermal and electrical energy and how they power our modern world.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student define and give examples of kinetic and potential energy, describe energy transformations, explain the Law of Conservation of Energy, and demonstrate understanding through experiments?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! We explored how energy moves and is stored, and saw how it can change from one type to another, like magic but it's science! Remember that energy is always around us, powering everything from your own body to the world. The most amazing part is that energy never actually gets lost, it just transforms, which is a huge concept in science!

parent_notes: Energy concepts connect to everything in science and daily life. The hands-on experiments make these abstract ideas concrete and observable. At home, look for energy transformations everywhere: a toaster converts electrical energy to thermal energy, a car converts chemical energy (gasoline) to kinetic energy, solar panels convert light energy to electrical energy. The Conservation of Energy is especially important — it means energy never disappears, only changes form. If your child asks 'Where did the energy go?' when something stops moving, the answer is usually heat and sound.

title: Cubism — Seeing from Every Angle at Once
description: Students explore the Cubist art movement pioneered by Pablo Picasso and Georges Braque, learning how these artists shattered traditional perspective by showing multiple viewpoints simultaneously. Students analyze Cubist works and create their own Cubist-style portraits or still lifes.
instructions:
1. Review Post-Impressionism as the foundation for modern art movements.
2. Introduce Cubism as a radical new way of seeing — showing all sides of an object at once.
3. Examine Picasso's 'Les Demoiselles d'Avignon' and discuss its revolutionary impact.
4. Study Braque's still lifes and identify geometric fragmentation.
5. Discuss the difference between Analytical Cubism (monochrome, fragmented) and Synthetic Cubism (colorful, collage).
6. Demonstrate how to draw a Cubist portrait: combine front view and profile in one image.
7. Show how to fragment a still life into geometric planes.
8. Students choose either a portrait or still life approach.
9. Create a Cubist artwork using geometric shapes and multiple perspectives.
10. Gallery walk and discuss how Cubism challenges our usual way of seeing.

slides.heading: Cubism
slides.subheading: Seeing from Every Angle at Once
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is introducing us to Cubism, which is a super cool art style where artists tried to show you an object or person from lots of different angles all at the same time, like you're spinning around it really fast. Think about looking at a toy car – you can see the front, the side, and the top, right? Cubist artists wanted to get all of that onto one flat picture!

slides.setup_instructions: Display Cubist art reproductions prominently. Set up art stations with drawing materials and optional collage supplies. Have mirrors available for students choosing self-portraits. Prepare geometric stencils.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is like our shopping list for becoming Cubist artists. We've got art examples so we can see what Cubism looks like, drawing paper, colorful pencils or pastels to make our art pop, rulers and stencils to help us make those geometric shapes, and even scissors and glue if we want to try a collage, which is like sticking pieces of paper together. Make sure you have all this stuff ready to go!

slides.text: Around 1907, Pablo PICASSO and Georges BRAQUE asked a revolutionary question: Why should a painting show only ONE viewpoint? In real life, you see objects from many angles — front, side, top, back. CUBISM attempts to show ALL these viewpoints at the SAME TIME in a single image. The result looks fractured and geometric, like looking through a shattered mirror.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step explains the big idea behind Cubism: why stick to just one view when you can show everything? Artists like Picasso and Braque realized that in real life, we see things from all sides, so they decided to paint that way too, breaking things up into geometric pieces to show the front, side, and top all at once. It's like looking at a face through a kaleidoscope, where you see all the parts but they're rearranged.

slides.text: Look at Picasso's faces: one eye might be shown from the front while the other is shown in profile. The nose might point sideways while the mouth faces forward. This is not a mistake — it is a deliberate attempt to show MORE INFORMATION than a traditional portrait can. Cubism sacrifices realistic appearance for a deeper kind of truth.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at how Cubist artists actually put those different views together in a painting, especially for portraits. Imagine drawing a face where one eye is looking straight at you, but the other eye is looking to the side, and the nose is sticking out sideways – it sounds weird, but it's how they showed you more of the person. They're not trying to make it look exactly like a photo, but more like how we really experience seeing something from every angle.

slides.text: ANALYTICAL CUBISM (1907-1912) broke objects into small geometric fragments using muted browns and grays. It looks like seeing an object through a prism. SYNTHETIC CUBISM (1912-1920s) added color, texture, and collage elements — pasting newspaper, fabric, and other materials onto the canvas. Both approaches challenged the idea that art must imitate reality.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide breaks down the two main types of Cubism: Analytical and Synthetic. Analytical Cubism, the earlier style, used lots of muted colors like browns and grays and broke things into tiny geometric shapes, almost like looking through a shattered piece of glass. Synthetic Cubism came later and was more colorful, and artists even started adding things like newspaper clippings or fabric to their paintings, making them feel more like a collage.

slides.text: To create a Cubist portrait: (1) Draw a face shape, but combine the front view and side view. (2) Place features at unexpected angles — an eye from the front next to an eye from the side. (3) Divide the background into geometric planes. (4) Use lines that extend from the face into the background, connecting figure and ground. (5) Color each geometric section differently to emphasize the fragmentation.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our instruction manual for drawing a Cubist portrait, so listen up! First, you'll sketch a face shape that mixes the front view and a side view together. Then, you'll place the eyes and other features in unexpected spots, like an eye from the front next to an eye from the side, and cut up the background into geometric shapes. Finally, you'll use lines to connect the face to the background and color each section differently to really make that fragmented look stand out.

slides.prompt: Create a Cubist artwork — choose your approach: OPTION A — CUBIST PORTRAIT: Using a mirror, observe your face from the front and side. Combine both views in one drawing. Fragment the background into geometric shapes. Color each section. OPTION B — CUBIST STILL LIFE: Arrange 3 simple objects (cup, book, fruit). Draw them showing multiple angles simultaneously — top, side, front all at once. Fragment with geometric lines. OPTION C — CUBIST COLLAGE: Cut geometric shapes from colored paper and newspaper. Arrange them to create a Cubist composition of a person or scene. Each approach should fill the entire page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to make some art! You get to choose your adventure: you can draw a Cubist portrait using a mirror to combine your front and side views, or you can arrange a few objects like a cup and a book and draw them from multiple angles at once for a still life. If you're feeling crafty, you can even cut out colored paper shapes and glue them together to make a Cubist collage. Whatever you choose, try to fill up the whole page and show things from different viewpoints!

slides.text: Cubism was perhaps the most radical art revolution in history. Picasso and Braque proved that art does not need to look like reality to be meaningful — in fact, by showing multiple viewpoints at once, Cubism might actually show MORE of reality than a traditional painting. Every form of modern art, design, and visual communication owes something to Cubism.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain the principles of Cubism, compare Analytical and Synthetic Cubism, identify works by Picasso and Braque, and create an artwork that shows multiple perspectives simultaneously?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we just explored Cubism, which totally changed how artists thought about painting and looking at the world! You learned that art doesn't have to look exactly like reality to be powerful, and by showing multiple viewpoints at once, Cubism actually revealed a deeper kind of truth. Think about how you saw a face or objects from every angle in your own artwork – that's the magic of Cubism that still influences art and design today!

parent_notes: Cubism can initially seem strange to children accustomed to realistic art, but it is also liberating — there is no 'wrong' way to draw a Cubist portrait. The key insight is that art can represent ideas and multiple viewpoints, not just what the eye sees from one position. Picasso's famous quote 'Every child is an artist; the problem is how to remain an artist once we grow up' is worth sharing. If your child says their Cubist art looks 'weird,' explain that Cubism was deliberately weird — it was breaking rules to create something new. Virtual museum visits to the Picasso Museum in Barcelona or MoMA in New York offer excellent Cubist collections.

title: Community Service Planning — Identifying Needs and Taking Action
description: Students learn to identify needs in their community and plan a service project from start to finish. They practice research, project planning, team coordination, and persuasive communication as they develop a proposal for a real community service initiative.
instructions:
1. Define community service and discuss why it matters.
2. Brainstorm community needs: who in our community could use help?
3. Categorize needs: environmental, social, educational, health-related.
4. Research local organizations and existing service opportunities.
5. Introduce project planning skills: goal, steps, timeline, resources, team roles.
6. Discuss realistic scope: what can students actually accomplish?
7. Model creating a service project proposal.
8. Students form teams and select a community need to address.
9. Teams create detailed project proposals with timelines.
10. Present proposals and vote on which project to pursue as a group.

slides.heading: Community Service Planning
slides.subheading: Identifying Needs and Taking Action
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to be doing: planning a community service project. Think of it like getting ready to build something cool – we're figuring out what we want to make and how we're going to do it. It's all about finding ways to help out in our neighborhoods and make things better for everyone.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a large brainstorming chart for community needs. Research local organizations and compile a reference list. Set up team workstations with poster board and planning templates.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide is like our toolkit for the project. We've got a chart to jot down ideas, a template to organize our plan, a list of places that already help out in our town, some poster board to make our ideas look awesome, markers, paper, and pencils. Make sure you have all these things ready to go so we can jump right into planning!

slides.text: COMMUNITY SERVICE means volunteering your time and skills to help others without expecting anything in return. It is one of the most important aspects of being a responsible citizen. Communities thrive when people look beyond their own needs and ask: 'How can I help?' Today, you will plan a REAL service project that could make a difference.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding what "community service" actually means. It's basically helping others in your town or city without getting paid, just because it's the right thing to do. Think about how good it feels when someone helps you – community service is about being that helper for someone else, and it makes our whole community stronger.

slides.text: The first step is identifying a genuine NEED. Look around your community: Are there elderly neighbors who need help with yard work? A park that needs cleaning? A food bank that needs donations? An animal shelter that needs supplies? A younger student who needs tutoring? The best service projects address REAL needs that you have observed or researched.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here, we're going to start thinking about *what* help is actually needed. Look around your own neighborhood, or even think about what you've seen on the news or heard from friends. Are there parks that could use a cleanup, or maybe older people who need help with chores? The goal is to spot a real problem that we can actually do something about.

slides.text: A good project plan answers: WHAT will you do? (Goal) WHO will help? (Team and roles) WHEN will each step happen? (Timeline) WHAT do you need? (Resources and materials) HOW will you know it worked? (Success measures) A project without a plan is just a wish — but a project WITH a plan can change your community.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is super important because it's how we turn an idea into a real plan. We need to figure out exactly what we want to achieve, who's going to do what, when things need to get done, what supplies we might need, and how we'll know if we've been successful. Without a plan, our good ideas might just stay as ideas, but a solid plan makes them happen.

slides.text: Keep your project REALISTIC. You are students, not an organization with unlimited resources. A single park cleanup day is more achievable than 'solving pollution.' Collecting 50 canned goods for a food bank is more realistic than 'ending hunger.' Start small, succeed, and then think bigger. Small actions done well have more impact than grand plans that never happen.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is about being smart with our time and energy. It's easy to have huge ideas, but we need to think about what we can *realistically* do as students. For example, cleaning up one park is a great goal, but trying to fix all the world's problems might be too much. Starting with something achievable means we'll actually get it done and feel good about it.

slides.prompt: Form teams of 3-4 students: (1) Brainstorm community needs your team has observed or learned about. List at least five. (2) Select ONE need your team wants to address. Explain why it matters. (3) Complete the project planning template: goal, steps, timeline (over 2-4 weeks), materials needed, team roles, and how you will measure success. (4) Create a proposal poster that presents your plan clearly and persuasively. (5) Prepare a 2-minute presentation to pitch your project to the class. Include: the need, your plan, why it will work, and what help you need.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to be creative and work with your team! You'll brainstorm problems in our community, pick one to focus on, and then fill out that planning sheet we talked about. After that, you'll make a poster to show off your amazing idea and get ready to convince the class why your project is the best one. You've got this!

slides.text: Planning a service project teaches leadership, teamwork, and compassion. You have identified real needs and created actionable plans. Next session, we will refine the winning proposal and begin organizing the project. Remember: every great community improvement started with someone asking 'How can I help?' — and then making a plan.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify genuine community needs, create a detailed service project plan with timeline and team roles, and present a persuasive proposal?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at everything you've accomplished today! You've figured out real ways to help people, made detailed plans, and even learned how to present your ideas. This is a huge step towards making a real difference in our community, and I can't wait to see what we do next!

parent_notes: Community service develops empathy, leadership, and civic responsibility. This lesson moves beyond theoretical discussion to actual project planning, giving your child a sense of agency. The project your child's team proposes may need your support to execute — consider volunteering to help. Service projects are most impactful when families participate together. Even if the classroom project does not proceed, you can help your child identify and act on community needs independently. Research shows that children who participate in service projects develop stronger social skills, greater empathy, and a deeper sense of purpose.

title: Research for Debate — Gathering and Evaluating Evidence
description: Students learn research skills specific to debate preparation, including how to find credible sources, evaluate evidence quality, organize research into argument categories, and prepare evidence cards. They apply these skills to research both sides of an upcoming debate topic.
instructions:
1. Review the CER and ACE frameworks from earlier in the week.
2. Discuss what makes a source credible: authority, accuracy, objectivity, currency.
3. Introduce the CRAAP test for evaluating sources: Currency, Relevance, Authority, Accuracy, Purpose.
4. Practice evaluating sample sources using the CRAAP test.
5. Model organizing research onto evidence cards: source, quote/fact, which argument it supports.
6. Discuss the importance of researching BOTH sides of a debate topic.
7. Assign debate topics for the week's culminating debate.
8. Students research their assigned topic using available resources.
9. Create evidence cards for both their side AND the opposing side.
10. Organize evidence into strongest-to-weakest order.
materials_needed: Research materials (books, printed articles, approved websites)

slides.heading: Research for Debate
slides.subheading: Gathering and Evaluating Evidence Like a Scholar
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is the title slide for our debate research lesson. It's basically telling us that to win a debate, we need to find really good information, called evidence, and make sure that information is trustworthy. Think of it like being a detective – you need solid clues to prove your case!

items: Research materials (books, printed articles, approved websites)
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare research stations with age-appropriate books, articles, and printed web pages on debate topics. Print CRAAP test sheets and evidence card templates. Prepare sample sources of varying quality for evaluation practice.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is like your shopping list for becoming a debate research pro. You've got the CRAAP test sheet to help you judge sources, blank evidence cards like mini-note cards for your facts, practice articles to try out your skills, actual research stuff like books and websites, a chart to keep your arguments straight, and pencils and highlighters to mark things up. Your teacher will help get these set up for you.

slides.text: A debate is only as strong as its EVIDENCE, and evidence is only as strong as its SOURCE. The CRAAP test helps you evaluate any source: CURRENCY — Is it recent enough to be relevant?
